texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This very elongated, slender, sand-dwelling species has eyes on top of the head and the lower jaw distinctly projecting. The dorsal fin has its origin above the vent and had 38–43 spines and 11–15 slightly longer rays. Pelvic fin consisting of 3 upturned rays connected by a membrane, like a frog-foot. Body colour cream, with a row of grey, darker-edged saddles dorsally and smaller spots along the flanks.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa to False Bay.

Found on clean sand and gravel substrata from low water mark to a depth of about  20 m, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually found buried in the sediment with only top of the head and eyes protruding. Able to insinuate itself quickly into the sand by wiggling the body side to side.
Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.

Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

There are three species in this genus, all with similar habits. The Slender platana klipfish C. burrelli is semi-transparent and cream with 12 small dark blotches along the back, while the Whiteblotched klipfish is white with fine purple blotching and two broad purple-brown bands across the body, the posterior one extending onto the tail.
